reviewText: I must admit I was totally suprised to get a refund after I gave a neutral review (3 stars) to the Chiefs DVD due to quality of the picture on my 55 inch TV. I did not make a claim for refund nor did I plan on returning the set, since I always enjoy the seires and it is watachable although not the digital quality most DVDs provide. I'd like to thank the distributor of refunding my money. It is rare that a company would do this only due to a neutral review and without being asked. In the future, I will surely consider purchaes from V2D, as I truely appreciate their customer satisfaction policy of the customer comes first. Thanks again .... BET
Title: N/A

reviewText: I've loved this mini-series since I first viewed it on CBS in the 80's (that network seemed to have all my favorites of that era: CHIEFS, A CHRISTMAS CAROL with George C. Scott, THE CAINE MUTINY COURT-MARTIAL, JACK THE RIPPER and LONESOME DOVE...all classics). But the old VHS tape on which I recorded CHIEFS is long gone, it's time for this mini-series to get a proper DVD release! I recently watched a special edition DVD box set of SHOGUN (helmed by CHIEFS director Jerry London), and it is a 5-disc beautifully remastered set with excellent video quality and 5.1 surround sound. I see no reason why CHIEFS can't receive the same treatment! In fact, I've heard the mini-series has been released in other countries with a 4-disc set...that would be ideal. 3 discs for the film and 1 for special features. I have a feeling it will happen soon, especially considering I've seen other mini-series as WINDS OF WAR available on DVD at the local stores! CHIEFS is a brilliant study about Americana as well as a taut compelling crime story! I can't wait until the day I can own a worthy copy of this masterpiece!

There is also the lives of these people that live in this town. Billie Dee Williams is the last sheriff they hire and he finds who is doing the killings. In Billy Dee Williams part, he has changed his real name for good reasons,in the movie you will see why and it's a kicker.Movie is on the pricey side, but well worth it.  Be careful, a lot of DVD's that are for sale are Region 2 and we in the USA can't play them.  It is a must buy.

reviewText: This mini-series is just as good as I remember it from my youth.  There are at least 4 amazing points in the series, and I loved pointing them out to my wife.Be sure to get the version that is 274 minutes long.  They note on this one that the audio was damaged, which I believe is why there is the shorter edited version, and that they have done the best with what they have.  The series is in English, as you would expect, but I believe the damage is why some of the credits are in German.  They also state that the quality isn't acceptable for the industry, but apparently, the show wasn't preserved properly.Easy recommendation, thought I think it does slow a bit in the 2nd episode.

reviewText: I loved this mini series when it was first aired. I later received the 2 tapes edition as a gift, but I was disappointed that many of the scenes were cut.I had read the book a few years after it was published.The story is about three police chiefs over a 38 year span in which brutal murders are committed.  This movie also deals with racial relations in the south during these different time periods.The actors were all terific, especially Billy Dee Williams and Wayne Rogers.  Both were exactly as I pictured their characters.The ending was especially touching when Billy Lee discovers that Tyler Watts is really Joshua Cole, a boyhood friend long lost.  This ending is different from the book, in which Billy Lee never learns who Tyler Watts is.Parts of this is sad, when Will Henry Lee and Marshall Peters are killed.  This is a tear jerker.Keith Caradine was perfect in the role of Foxy, who was a very menacing and scary guy.I hope to see this on DVD soon.  Does anyone know why this is not available?  If so, please enlighten me. I am tempted to buy a region 2 player, since that particular DVD is available.I am hoping that the DVD will be released soon as originally aired without any cutting out of scenes.

reviewText: I was happy to find this older title on DVD. I know some older films and television shows can be expensive, but this one was certainly worth the price to me. I have waited a long time to see this at a more reasonable price as I had seen imports sell for over 60 dollars. Many of the TV based movies and mini-series are not available, and are no longer broadcasted. I saw this when it came out, and wanted it on DVD since I no longer have my videotaped copy. Since I do purchase quite a few DVDs, I am trying to get some of the older ones now as the price seems to be going up in this age of instant video downloads. While many older shows may not have the same picture quality as today's do, this one is plenty good enough to bring back memories of seeing it on TV and sort of wishing I was back in that time period. Nostalgia fix? Yes it is!
summary: Glad to see this on DVD.

reviewText: A good look at police power gone wrong. The sheriff looks out for his buddies with little concern for his clients, the county citizens. It also shows the ugly face of racism in this case also the criminal actions of the Clan aka the KKK. I'd recommend all Southern Rednecks to watch this movie and learn from it. Lots of brutality. Carlton Heston as the city of Dalton's Patriarch did a superb job. It's a good movie for a broad adult audience. Don't expect the viewing quality of today's DVD's tho. It's been, as good as possible, formatted  from VHS onto DVD.

reviewText: I have been a reader for 44 years, since I was 12 years old.  CHIEFS is one of the best books I have ever read.  It was not until I was finished with it that I found out it had been a mini-series on TV in the 80s.  The story is full of honorable men doing their best against many prejudices in the South.  It took 43 years to solve the mystery of the missing youths and who their killer was.  I said to my husband - boy you'd like this if it were a movie.  The snaking plot(s) fit right in with what I like to watch on TV.  A touch of the Old West, small town living, Southern attitudes, and heroes!

reviewText: I still place Stuart Woods's "Chiefs" among the best police dramas ever written. Since I learned that a TV adaptation of the book was made, I've always wanted to see it - and, about a year ago, I finally found and bought the DVD release of the series (which seems to be unavailable outside R2). I actually did not expect much, but what I received surprised me - and it was a positive surprise. The series is an excellent adaptation of the novel and manages to do it justice, which is a rarity... as is the fact that very little of the book's plot is omitted. Certainly, some of the details - such as Will Henry's growing obsession with the mysterious murders, and the technical sides of his investigation - have to be treated superficially, but every important subplot and aspect of the book is present in the film; consequently, the series manages to be just as thrilling and involving as the novel. Amusingly enough, the credits on the box of the DVD misled me slightly - I assumed Charlton Heston, Keith Carradine and Billy Dee Williams would be playing the three chiefs, chronologically; of course, this is not the case. Of course, a Collector's Edition, with some extras and a commentary (perhaps even by Stuart Woods?) would be even better, since the DVD I have is bare-bones, with only a spartan menu and chapter selection, but that's unlikely to happen with a TV series. Then again, it's been done with, for instance, "IT!", so... you never know. If a Special Edition DVD is ever released, I'll certainly buy it in addition to the standard one I have.

reviewText: This is a review of the mini series and not of the DVD or format. It is excellent and one of the best mini series ever on television--a standout. Hopefully, more choices and formats will become available to the general public so thay can watch this engrossing production, in its full and un-condensed and un-edited version.  It is Deep-Southy in location and studies both the noble and also sinister attributes of three generations of police chiefs in a Southern family, Southern Georgia town.  All of the players are at their best, Heston, Carridine, Collins, Williams, et. al.

reviewText: This miniseries comes from back in the days before all you had to do to call a movie a "miniseries" was to make it big enough that it had to run on two or more nights. It's the same logic as using the term "box set" for any audio CD that requires two discs. Okay--end of rant.Failing farmer Will Henry Lee (Wayne Rogers) decides to accept the job of Delano's first chief of police rather than dig himself further into debt with credit extensions banker Hugh Holmes (Charlton Heston) still would have approved. But Holmes in his other role of the town's most prominent citizen agrees with Will Henry on his career change--he's the one who suggests the new job to him to begin with and supports his candidacy. Holmes also serves as voice-over narrator at intervals during the film. One person who does not agree is Sheriff Skeeter Willis (Paul Sorvino), who feels that Will Henry is not tough enough to be a cop. One other citizen who shares that view is reclusive landowner Foxy Funderburke (Keith Carradine), who was the other candidate for the job and didn't get chosen. Funderburke serves as the cliché "mad hermit" of the story. The story runs through an epic five decades, with other stars such as Billy Dee Williams as the first black chief much later in the film, plus Victoria Tennant (who we know from her co-starring role in "Winds Of War/ War and Remembrance") as the beautiful and gutsy English "war bride" of Will Henry's son Billy.Now as for the lousy sound. According to a disclaimer slide at the beginning of this DVD version, the original film suffered a lot of damage to the soundtrack while in storage, so it can't be helped. I believe I still have VHS tapes of this miniseries I grabbed off the air which sound better. But we'll have to wait for whatever tech improvements clean that up if there is a later version of this. It really is only that bad at first and I got used to it within a few minutes. At least you don't get synch problems between the audio and the picture.
summary: It Gets Only 3 Stars For Lousy Sound.

reviewText: Although the storyline is very good and the big-name actors a plus, if you are a videophile you will want to avoid this particular DVD version. Although the audio is very good, the video leaves much to be desired. The image is slightly out of focus (the FBI warning is, however, very sharp); the color is off...too much red; and the contrast is weak, giving a slightly washed out appearance. Additionally the compression rate is too high, resulting in severe "pixelation" in action scenes and some scene changes. Even the frame rate was slightly off, causing intermittent frame freezing, which is odd because this was a made-for-TV feature. The VHS recordings I made 30 years ago of the original broadcast still have better video quality than this DVD (unfortunately, the audio on those tapes has deteriorated to very poor quality). I'm not a videophile, so I found the poor video quality somewhat less than distracting, just disappointing. If you want a high quality DVD version, you'll have to wait until someone does a professional transfer from the original masters, if ever. But, if you can overlook the poor video quality, it's an enjoyable movie. I would also mention that the original broadcast was in three parts, while this version was done as one part spread across two DVDs - I would have preferred the original 3-part presentation.
summary: One of the worst video transfers I have seen.
